clinical_study.brief_title: Efficacy and Safety of Etanercept 50 mg Once Weekly Plus As Needed Topical Agent in Moderate to Severe Plaque Psoriasis
clinical_study.official_title: A Randomized, Blinded Assessor Study to Evaluate the Efficacy and Safety of Etanercept 50 mg Once Weekly Plus As Needed Topical Agent Versus Etanercept 50 mg Twice Weekly in Subjects With Moderate to Severe Plaque Psoriasis

brief_summary.textblock: To estimate the difference in effectiveness between treatment with etanercept 50 mg twice weekly (BIW) and treatment with etanercept 50 mg once weekly (QW) plus an as needed (PRN) topical agent for 12 weeks in adults with moderate to severe plaque psoriasis.

detailed_description.textblock:
The recommended starting dose of etanercept for adult plaque psoriasis patients is a 50 mg dose given twice a week (BIW) for 3 months followed by a reduction to a maintenance dose of 50 mg once weekly (QW). While most patients with moderate to severe plaque psoriasis are managed satisfactorily on etanercept monotherapy, a proportion may require a modified or alternative treatment regimen (eg, to handle flares or loss of effect) at some point during their chronic management. Despite the clinical need, no published data from randomized controlled studies are currently available that demonstrate efficacy and safety of combined etanercept-based regimens in patients with plaque psoriasis.
The addition of an as-needed topical medication to the step-down dose of etanercept 50 mg once weekly administered after the initial 12 week period of 50 mg twice weekly may be a potential option for patients who may require adjunctive therapy. This study aimed to provide data on this treatment option by estimating the difference in mean percent change in Psoriasis Area and Severity Index (PASI) scores between step-down etanercept 50 mg once weekly supplemented with as-needed topical medication and continuous treatment with etanercept 50 mg twice weekly.
Eligible patients will be enrolled in the study and will receive etanercept 50 mg twice weekly for 12 weeks. After 12 weeks of etanercept treatment, participants will be randomized in a 1:1 ratio to 1 of 2 treatment groups.

primary_outcome.measure: Percent Change in Psoriasis Area and Severity Index (PASI) From Week 12 to Week 24
primary_outcome.description: The Psoriasis Area and Severity Index (PASI) score is a combination of the intensity of psoriasis, assessed by the erythema (reddening), induration (plaque thickness) and desquamation (scaling) on a scale from none (0), mild (1), moderate (2), severe (3) or very severe (4), together with the percentage of the area affected, rated on a scale from 0 to 6. PASI scoring is performed at four body areas, the head, arms, trunk, and legs. The total PASI score ranges from 0 to 72. The higher the total score, the more severe the disease. Change from Week 12 to Week 24 is presented as a percentage of the Week 12 value: Week 12 value - Week 24 value / Week 12 value * 100 so that a positive change indicates improvement. Change was adjusted for treatment using a mixed model.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percent Change in PASI From Week 12 to Weeks 16 and 20
secondary_outcome.description: The Psoriasis Area and Severity Index (PASI) score is a combination of the intensity of psoriasis, assessed by the erythema (reddening), induration (plaque thickness) and desquamation (scaling) on a scale from none (0), mild (1), moderate (2), severe (3) or very severe (4), together with the percentage of the area affected, rated on a scale from 0 to 6. PASI scoring is performed at four body areas, the head, arms, trunk, and legs. The total PASI score ranges from 0 to 72. The higher the total score, the more severe the disease. Change from Week 12 presented as a percentage of the Week 12 value: Week 12 value - postbaseline value / Week 12 value * 100, so that a positive change indicates improvement. Change was adjusted for treatment using a mixed model.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percent Change in PASI From Baseline to Weeks 12, 16, 20, and 24
secondary_outcome.description: The Psoriasis Area and Severity Index (PASI) score is a combination of the intensity of psoriasis, assessed by the erythema (reddening), induration (plaque thickness) and desquamation (scaling) on a scale from none (0), mild (1), moderate (2), severe (3) or very severe (4), together with the percentage of the area affected, rated on a scale from 0 to 6. PASI scoring is performed at four body areas, the head, arms, trunk, and legs. The total PASI score ranges from 0 to 72. The higher the total score, the more severe the disease. Change from Baseline is presented as a percentage of the Baseline value: Baseline value - postbaseline value / Baseline value * 100, so that a positive change indicates improvement.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With a PASI 50 Response
secondary_outcome.description: The percentage of participants with a 50% reduction (improvement) in Psoriasis Area and Severity Index (PASI) score from Baseline. PASI score is based on an assessment of erythema (reddening), induration (plaque thickness), desquamation (scaling), and the percent area affected as observed on the day of examination. The score ranges from 0 (best outcome) to 72 (worst outcome).

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With a PASI 75 Response
secondary_outcome.description: The percentage of participants with a 75% reduction (improvement) in Psoriasis Area and Severity Index (PASI) score from Baseline. PASI score is based on an assessment of erythema (reddening), induration (plaque thickness), desquamation (scaling), and the percent area affected as observed on the day of examination. The score ranges from 0 (best outcome) to 72 (worst outcome).

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With a PASI 90 Response
secondary_outcome.description: The percentage of participants with a 90% reduction (improvement) in Psoriasis Area and Severity Index (PASI) score from Baseline. PASI score is based on an assessment of erythema (reddening), induration (plaque thickness), desquamation (scaling), and the percent area affected as observed on the day of examination. The score ranges from 0 (best outcome) to 72 (worst outcome).

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With a Static Physician's Global Assessment (sPGA) of Psoriasis Score of 0 (Clear) or 1 (Almost Clear)
secondary_outcome.description: The sPGA scale is completed by the same blinded assessor performing the PASI assessments and is designed to evaluate the physician's global assessment of the participant's psoriasis based on severity of induration, scaling, and erythema. The sPGA is assessed on a scale of 0 to 5 (0 = clear, 5 = severe).

secondary_outcome.measure: Percent Change in the Percentage of Body Surface Area (BSA) Involvement From Week 12 to Weeks 16, 20, and 24
secondary_outcome.description: The percentage of body surface area involved with psoriasis was measured by the same blinded assessor performing the PASI assessments. Change from Week 12 is presented as a percentage of the Week 12 value: Week 12 value - postbaseline value / Week 12 value * 100, so that a positive change indicates improvement. Change was adjusted for treatment using a mixed model.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percent Change in the Percentage of Body Surface Area (BSA) Involvement From Baseline to Weeks 12, 16, 20, and 24
secondary_outcome.description: The percentage of body surface area involved with psoriasis was measured by the same blinded assessor performing the PASI assessments. Change from Baseline \ is presented as a percentage of the Baseline value: Baseline value - postbaseline value / Baseline value * 100, so that a positive change indicates improvement.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Week 12 to Week 24 in Dermatology Quality of Life Index (DQLI) Total Score
secondary_outcome.description: The DLQI questionnaire asks participants to evaluate the degree that psoriasis has affected their quality of life in the last week, and includes the following parameters: symptoms and feelings, daily activities, leisure activities, work or school activities, personal relationships and treatment related feelings. Participants answer 10 questions on a scale from 0 (not at all) to 3 (very much); the range of the total score is 0 to 30. A score of 21 to 30 means an extremely large effect on the participant's life whereas 0-1 means that the disease has no effect at all. Change from Week 12 to Week 24 is calculated as: Week 12 value - Week 24 value so that a positive change indicates improvement. Change was adjusted for treatment using a mixed model.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline to Weeks 12 and 24 in Dermatology Quality of Life Index (DQLI) Total Score
secondary_outcome.description: The DLQI questionnaire asks participants to evaluate the degree that psoriasis has affected their quality of life in the last week, and includes the following parameters: symptoms and feelings, daily activities, leisure activities, work or school activities, personal relationships and treatment related feelings. Participants answer 10 questions on a scale from 0 (not at all) to 3 (very much); the range of the total score is 0 to 30. A score of 21 to 30 means an extremely large effect on the participant's life whereas 0-1 means that the disease has no effect at all. Change from Baseline was calculated as Baseline value - postbaseline value so that a positive change indicates improvement.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Treatment Satisfaction Questionnaire for Medications (TSQM) Scores From Week 12 to Week 24
secondary_outcome.description: TSQM is a validated questionnaire consisting of 14 questions regarding a participant's perception of the level of satisfaction or dissatisfaction with the medication they are taking. Four scales are generated: side effects, effectiveness, convenience, and global satisfaction. Optional responses are: Extremely Dissatisfied, Very Dissatisfied, Dissatisfied, Somewhat Satisfied, Satisfied, Very Satisfied, and Extremely Satisfied. From the responses, a scale score from 0 - 100 is calculated, with a higher score indicating greater satisfaction. Change was calculated as Week 24 - Week 12 so that a positive change indicates improvement over time. Change was adjusted for treatment using a mixed model.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Treatment Satisfaction Questionnaire for Medications (TSQM) Scores From Baseline to Weeks 12 and 24
secondary_outcome.description: The TSQM is a validated questionnaire consisting of 14 questions regarding a participant's perception of the level of satisfaction or dissatisfaction with the medication they are taking. Four scales are generated: side effects, effectiveness, convenience, and global satisfaction. Optional responses are: Extremely Dissatisfied, Very Dissatisfied, Dissatisfied, Somewhat Satisfied, Satisfied, Very Satisfied, and Extremely Satisfied. From the responses, a scale score from 0 - 100 is calculated, with a higher score indicating greater satisfaction. Change was calculated as postbaseline value - Baseline value so that a positive change indicates improvement.

secondary_outcome.measure: Health Resource Utilization: Number of Participants With Visits to a Healthcare Provider
secondary_outcome.description: Participants completed a questionnaire to assess their health resource utilization (HRU) related to psoriasis. To assess the number of visits to a healthcare provider, participants answered the following questions regarding the past 4 weeks: How many times have you been to any physician's office or urgent care clinic? How many times have you seen a nurse practitioner, a physician assistant, a psychologist, a naturopath, an acupuncturist, a chiropractor, or other healthcare professional (HCP)? The number of participants with one or more visits is reported.

secondary_outcome.measure: Health Resource Utilization: Number of Participants With Home Healthcare Visits
secondary_outcome.description: Participants completed a questionnaire to assess their health resource utilization (HRU) related to psoriasis. To assess the number of homecare visits, participants answered the following question regarding the past 4 weeks: How many times have you received care from a health professional in your home? The number of participants with one or more visits is reported.

secondary_outcome.measure: Health Resource Utilization: Number of Participants Requiring Paid Help With Chores
secondary_outcome.description: Participants completed a questionnaire to assess their health resource utilization (HRU) related to psoriasis. To assess the number of participants who needed paid help with chores, participants answered the following question regarding the past 4 weeks: How many times have you paid someone to help you do chores around the house (cleaning, maintenance, lawn care)? The number of participants who paid for help one or more times is reported.

secondary_outcome.measure: Health Resource Utilization: Number of Participants Who Needed Friend or Family Care
secondary_outcome.description: Participants completed a questionnaire to assess their health resource utilization (HRU) related to psoriasis. Participants answered the following question regarding the past 4 weeks: How many hours have you had a friend or family member take time off work to provide care or transportation? The number of participants who had paid or non-paid help for one or more hours is reported.

secondary_outcome.measure: Health Resource Utilization: Out of Pocket Expenses
secondary_outcome.description: Participants completed a questionnaire to assess their health resource utilization (HRU) related to psoriasis. To assess out of pocket expenses, participants answered the following question regarding the past 4 weeks: Not counting study mandated visits, what out-of-pocket expenses did you spend for the management of psoriasis (i.e. costs due to travelling to doctor appointment, hospital or clinic parking costs, alternative medications)?

secondary_outcome.measure: Health Resource Utilization: Employment Status
secondary_outcome.description: Participants completed a questionnaire to assess their health resource utilization (HRU) related to psoriasis. Participants were asked their employment status at Baseline and at Week 24.

secondary_outcome.measure: Health Resource Utilization: Productivity While Working
secondary_outcome.description: Participants who were employed were asked: How much did your psoriasis affect your productivity while you were working? Possible responses were: a) A great deal; b) Quite a bit; c) Somewhat; d) Minimally; e) Not at all.

secondary_outcome.measure: Health Resource Utilization: Number of Participants With Missed Hours From Work
secondary_outcome.description: Participants who were employed answered the following question regarding the past 4 weeks: How many hours per week did you miss from work because of your psoriasis? The number of participants with one or more missed hours of work per week is reported.

secondary_outcome.measure: Health Resource Utilization: Ability to Perform Daily Activities
secondary_outcome.description: Participants were asked: How much did your psoriasis affect your ability to do your daily activities or household chores? Possible answers were: a) A great deal; b) Quite a bit; c) Somewhat; d) Minimally; e) Not at all.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Adverse Events
secondary_outcome.description: An adverse event (AE) is defined as any untoward medical occurrence in a clinical trial participant. A serious adverse event is defined as an adverse event that meets at least 1 of the following serious criteria: • fatal, • life threatening, • requires in-patient hospitalization or prolongation of existing hospitalization, • results in persistent or significant disability/incapacity, • congenital anomaly/birth defect, and/or • other significant medical hazard.

arm_group.description: Following 12 weeks of etanercept 50 mg twice weekly, participants were randomized to 50 mg etanercept twice weekly for 12 weeks.
Following 12 weeks of etanercept 50 mg twice weekly, participants were randomized to 50 mg etanercept once weekly plus as needed topical agents.

intervention.description: Topical agents prescribed at the discretion of the Principal Investigator and were are limited to the following: hydrocortisone 2.5% betamethasone valerate 0.1% betamethasone dipropionate 0.05% clobetasol 0.05% calcitriol calcipotriol plus betamethsone dipropionate 0.05%

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Has had stable moderate to severe plaque psoriasis for at least 6 months (eg, no morphology changes or significant flares of disease activity in the opinion of the investigator).
- Has a body surface area (BSA) involvement ≥ 10% and Psoriasis Area and Severity Index (PASI) ≥ 10 at screening and at baseline.
- Is a candidate for systemic therapy or phototherapy in the opinion of the investigator.
- Other inclusion criteria may apply.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Has active guttate, erythrodermic, or pustular psoriasis at the time of the screening visit.
- Has evidence of skin conditions at the time of the screening visit (eg, eczema) that would interfere with evaluations of the effect of etanercept on psoriasis.
- Diagnosed with medication-induced or medication-exacerbated psoriasis.
- Significant concurrent medical conditions.
- Has any active localized infection; requiring local intervention or chronic or localized infections.
- Other exclusion criteria may apply.

reference.citation: Papp KA, Barber K, Bissonnette R, Bourcier M, Lynde CW, Poulin Y, Shelton J, Garces K, Toole J, Poulin-Costello M. Improvements in patient-reported outcomes in patients with psoriasis receiving etanercept plus topical therapies: results from REFINE. J Eur Acad Dermatol Venereol. 2015 Aug;29(8):1555-61. doi: 10.1111/jdv.12934. Epub 2015 Jan 21.

Papp KA, Barber K, Bissonnette R, Bourcier M, Lynde CW, Poulin Y, Shelton J, Toole J, Vieira A, Poulin-Costello M. A Randomized, blinded assessor study to Evaluate the efFIcacy and safety of etanercept 50 mg once weekly plus as Needed topical agent vs. Etanercept 50 mg twice weekly in patients with moderate to severe plaque psoriasis (REFINE). J Eur Acad Dermatol Venereol. 2015 Feb;29(2):361-6. doi: 10.1111/jdv.12555. Epub 2014 Jul 1.

Gooderham MJ, Poulin-Costello M, Shelton J, Bayan N, Papp KA. Predictors of Topical Use in Psoriasis Patients in the REFINE Study. J Cutan Med Surg. 2016 Mar-Apr;20(2):106-12. doi: 10.1177/1203475415604322. Epub 2015 Sep 1.

participant_flow.recruitment_details: First patient enrollment :29 April 2011; last patient enrollment: 4 June 2012.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: A total of 414 patients were screened,310 patients were enrolled and 287 randomized in this study; 144 in the etanercept monotherapy group (group A) and 143 in the etanercept plus an as-needed topical agent group (group B). 23 patients were not randomized because they did not complete the 12-week open-label treatment period before randomization.

group.title: Etanercept 50 mg BIW
group.description: Following 12 weeks of etanercept 50 mg twice weekly (BIW), participants were randomized to 50 mg etanercept by subcutaneous injection twice weekly for 12 weeks.

group.title: Etanercept 50 mg QW + Topical
group.description: Following 12 weeks of etanercept 50 mg twice weekly, participants were randomized to 50 mg subcutaneous injection once weekly (QW) plus as needed topical agents.

group.title: Non-randomized
group.description: Enrolled participants received etanercept 50 mg twice weekly but discontinued prior to completing the 12-week open-label treatment period.

group.title: Etanercept 50 mg BIW
group.description: Following 12 weeks of etanercept 50 mg twice weekly (BIW), participants were randomized to 50 mg etanercept by subcutaneous injection twice weekly for 12 weeks.

group.title: Etanercept 50 mg QW + Topical
group.description: Following 12 weeks of etanercept 50 mg twice weekly, participants were randomized to 50 mg subcutaneous injection once weekly (QW) plus as needed topical agents.

group.title: Non-randomized
group.description: Enrolled participants received etanercept 50 mg twice weekly but discontinued prior to completing the 12-week open-label treatment period.

group.title: Total
group.description: Total of all reporting groups

Sex: Female, Male
Race/Ethnicity, Customized
Body Mass Index (BMI)
Prior anti-Tumor Necrosis Factor (TNF) Treatment
measure.description: Based on participants in the Efficacy Evaluable set, all randomized participants, who had taken at least 1 dose of study drug and had at least 1 postrandomization efficacy evaluation (140 and 142 particiapants in each randomized treatment group respectively).

measurement_list.measurement: Total not calculated because data are not available (NA) in one or more arms.
Total not calculated because data are not available (NA) in one or more arms.

outcome.title: Percent Change in Psoriasis Area and Severity Index (PASI) From Week 12 to Week 24
outcome.description: The Psoriasis Area and Severity Index (PASI) score is a combination of the intensity of psoriasis, assessed by the erythema (reddening), induration (plaque thickness) and desquamation (scaling) on a scale from none (0), mild (1), moderate (2), severe (3) or very severe (4), together with the percentage of the area affected, rated on a scale from 0 to 6. PASI scoring is performed at four body areas, the head, arms, trunk, and legs. The total PASI score ranges from 0 to 72. The higher the total score, the more severe the disease. Change from Week 12 to Week 24 is presented as a percentage of the Week 12 value: Week 12 value - Week 24 value / Week 12 value * 100 so that a positive change indicates improvement. Change was adjusted for treatment using a mixed model.
outcome.population: Efficacy Evaluable set, which included all randomized participants who had taken at least 1 dose of study drug and had at least 1 post-randomization efficacy evaluation, and with available data at Week 12 and Week 24.

outcome.title: Percent Change in PASI From Baseline to Weeks 12, 16, 20, and 24
outcome.description: The Psoriasis Area and Severity Index (PASI) score is a combination of the intensity of psoriasis, assessed by the erythema (reddening), induration (plaque thickness) and desquamation (scaling) on a scale from none (0), mild (1), moderate (2), severe (3) or very severe (4), together with the percentage of the area affected, rated on a scale from 0 to 6. PASI scoring is performed at four body areas, the head, arms, trunk, and legs. The total PASI score ranges from 0 to 72. The higher the total score, the more severe the disease. Change from Baseline is presented as a percentage of the Baseline value: Baseline value - postbaseline value / Baseline value * 100, so that a positive change indicates improvement.
outcome.population: Full analysis set, (all enrolled participants who had taken at least 1 dose of study treatment and had at least 1 post-baseline efficacy evaluation) and with available data. Last Observation Carried Forward (LOCF) imputation was used.

outcome.title: Percentage of Participants With a PASI 50 Response
outcome.description: The percentage of participants with a 50% reduction (improvement) in Psoriasis Area and Severity Index (PASI) score from Baseline. PASI score is based on an assessment of erythema (reddening), induration (plaque thickness), desquamation (scaling), and the percent area affected as observed on the day of examination. The score ranges from 0 (best outcome) to 72 (worst outcome).

outcome.title: Percentage of Participants With a Static Physician’s Global Assessment (sPGA) of Psoriasis Score of 0 (Clear) or 1 (Almost Clear)
outcome.description: The sPGA scale is completed by the same blinded assessor performing the PASI assessments and is designed to evaluate the physician’s global assessment of the participant’s psoriasis based on severity of induration, scaling, and erythema. The sPGA is assessed on a scale of 0 to 5 (0 = clear, 5 = severe).
outcome.population: Full Analysis Set, LOCF was used.

group.title: Etanercept 50 mg BIW
group.description: Following 12 weeks of etanercept 50 mg twice weekly (BIW), participants were randomized to 50 mg etanercept by subcutaneous injection twice weekly for 12 weeks.

group.title: Etanercept 50 mg QW + Topical
group.description: Following 12 weeks of etanercept 50 mg twice weekly, participants were randomized to 50 mg subcutaneous injection once weekly (QW) plus as needed topical agents.

measure.title: Percentage of Participants With a Static Physician’s Global Assessment (sPGA) of Psoriasis Score of 0 (Clear) or 1 (Almost Clear)
measure.description: The sPGA scale is completed by the same blinded assessor performing the PASI assessments and is designed to evaluate the physician’s global assessment of the participant’s psoriasis based on severity of induration, scaling, and erythema. The sPGA is assessed on a scale of 0 to 5 (0 = clear, 5 = severe).
measure.population: Full Analysis Set, LOCF was used.

outcome.title: Percent Change in the Percentage of Body Surface Area (BSA) Involvement From Week 12 to Weeks 16, 20, and 24
outcome.description: The percentage of body surface area involved with psoriasis was measured by the same blinded assessor performing the PASI assessments. Change from Week 12 is presented as a percentage of the Week 12 value: Week 12 value - postbaseline value / Week 12 value * 100, so that a positive change indicates improvement. Change was adjusted for treatment using a mixed model.
outcome.population: Efficacy analysis set with available data

group.title: Etanercept 50 mg BIW
group.description: Following 12 weeks of etanercept 50 mg twice weekly (BIW), participants were randomized to 50 mg etanercept by subcutaneous injection twice weekly for 12 weeks.

group.title: Etanercept 50 mg QW + Topical
group.description: Following 12 weeks of etanercept 50 mg twice weekly, participants were randomized to 50 mg subcutaneous injection once weekly (QW) plus as needed topical agents.

Change from Week 12 is presented as a percentage of the Week 12 value: Week 12 value - postbaseline value / Week 12 value * 100, so that a positive change indicates improvement. Change was adjusted for treatment using a mixed model.
measure.population: Efficacy analysis set with available data

outcome.description: The percentage of body surface area involved with psoriasis was measured by the same blinded assessor performing the PASI assessments. Change from Baseline \ is presented as a percentage of the Baseline value: Baseline value - postbaseline value / Baseline value * 100, so that a positive change indicates improvement.
outcome.population: Full analysis set with available data; LOCF was used

group.title: Etanercept 50 mg BIW
group.description: Following 12 weeks of etanercept 50 mg twice weekly (BIW), participants were randomized to 50 mg etanercept by subcutaneous injection twice weekly for 12 weeks.

group.title: Etanercept 50 mg QW + Topical
group.description: Following 12 weeks of etanercept 50 mg twice weekly, participants were randomized to 50 mg subcutaneous injection once weekly (QW) plus as needed topical agents.

measure.title: Percent Change in the Percentage of Body Surface Area (BSA) Involvement From Baseline to Weeks 12, 16, 20, and 24
measure.description: The percentage of body surface area involved with psoriasis was measured by the same blinded assessor performing the PASI assessments. Change from Baseline \ is presented as a percentage of the Baseline value: Baseline value - postbaseline value / Baseline value * 100, so that a positive change indicates improvement.
measure.population: Full analysis set with available data; LOCF was used

outcome.title: Change From Week 12 to Week 24 in Dermatology Quality of Life Index (DQLI) Total Score
outcome.description: The DLQI questionnaire asks participants to evaluate the degree that psoriasis has affected their quality of life in the last week, and includes the following parameters: symptoms and feelings, daily activities, leisure activities, work or school activities, personal relationships and treatment related feelings. Participants answer 10 questions on a scale from 0 (not at all) to 3 (very much); the range of the total score is 0 to 30. A score of 21 to 30 means an extremely large effect on the participant's life whereas 0-1 means that the disease has no effect at all. Change from Week 12 to Week 24 is calculated as: Week 12 value - Week 24 value so that a positive change indicates improvement. Change was adjusted for treatment using a mixed model.
outcome.population: Efficacy Evaluable set with available data

group.title: Etanercept 50 mg BIW
group.description: Following 12 weeks of etanercept 50 mg twice weekly (BIW), participants were randomized to 50 mg etanercept by subcutaneous injection twice weekly for 12 weeks.

group.title: Etanercept 50 mg QW + Topical
group.description: Following 12 weeks of etanercept 50 mg twice weekly, participants were randomized to 50 mg subcutaneous injection once weekly (QW) plus as needed topical agents.

Participants answer 10 questions on a scale from 0 (not at all) to 3 (very much); the range of the total score is 0 to 30. Participants answer 10 questions on a scale from 0 (not at all) to 3 (very much); the range of the total score is 0 to 30. A score of 21 to 30 means an extremely large effect on the participant's life whereas 0-1 means that the disease has no effect at all. Change from Baseline was calculated as Baseline value - postbaseline value so that a positive change indicates improvement.

measure.description: The DLQI questionnaire asks participants to evaluate the degree that psoriasis has affected their quality of life in the last week, and includes the following parameters: symptoms and feelings, daily activities, leisure activities, work or school activities, personal relationships and treatment related feelings. Participants answer 10 questions on a scale from 0 (not at all) to 3 (very much); the range of the total score is 0 to 30. A score of 21 to 30 means an extremely large effect on the participant's life whereas 0-1 means that the disease has no effect at all. Change from Baseline was calculated as Baseline value - postbaseline value so that a positive change indicates improvement.

outcome.title: Change in Treatment Satisfaction Questionnaire for Medications (TSQM) Scores From Week 12 to Week 24
outcome.description: TSQM is a validated questionnaire consisting of 14 questions regarding a participant's perception of the level of satisfaction or dissatisfaction with the medication they are taking. Four scales are generated: side effects, effectiveness, convenience, and global satisfaction. Optional responses are: Extremely Dissatisfied, Very Dissatisfied, Dissatisfied, Somewhat Satisfied, Satisfied, Very Satisfied, and Extremely Satisfied. From the responses, a scale score from 0 - 100 is calculated, with a higher score indicating greater satisfaction. Change was calculated as Week 24 - Week 12 so that a positive change indicates improvement over time. Change was adjusted for treatment using a mixed model.
outcome.population: Efficacy Evaluable with available data; n indicates the number of patients with available data for each scale.

group.title: Etanercept 50 mg BIW
group.description: Following 12 weeks of etanercept 50 mg twice weekly (BIW), participants were randomized to 50 mg etanercept by subcutaneous injection twice weekly for 12 weeks.

group.title: Etanercept 50 mg QW + Topical
group.description: Following 12 weeks of etanercept 50 mg twice weekly, participants were randomized to 50 mg subcutaneous injection once weekly (QW) plus as needed topical agents.

measure.description: TSQM is a validated questionnaire consisting of 14 questions regarding a participant's perception of the level of satisfaction or dissatisfaction with the medication they are taking. Four scales are generated: side effects, effectiveness, convenience, and global satisfaction. Optional responses are: Extremely Dissatisfied, Very Dissatisfied, Dissatisfied, Somewhat Satisfied, Satisfied, Very Satisfied, and Extremely Satisfied. From the responses, a scale score from 0 - 100 is calculated, with a higher score indicating greater satisfaction. Change was calculated as Week 24 - Week 12 so that a positive change indicates improvement over time. Change was adjusted for treatment using a mixed model.
measure.population: Efficacy Evaluable with available data; n indicates the number of patients with available data for each scale.

outcome.title: Change in Treatment Satisfaction Questionnaire for Medications (TSQM) Scores From Baseline to Weeks 12 and 24
outcome.description: The TSQM is a validated questionnaire consisting of 14 questions regarding a participant's perception of the level of satisfaction or dissatisfaction with the medication they are taking. Four scales are generated: side effects, effectiveness, convenience, and global satisfaction. Optional responses are: Extremely Dissatisfied, Very Dissatisfied, Dissatisfied, Somewhat Satisfied, Satisfied, Very Satisfied, and Extremely Satisfied. From the responses, a scale score from 0 - 100 is calculated, with a higher score indicating greater satisfaction. Change was calculated as postbaseline value - Baseline value so that a positive change indicates improvement.
outcome.population: Full analysis set; LOCF was used; n indicates the number of patients with available data for each scale at each time point.

group.title: Etanercept 50 mg BIW
group.description: Following 12 weeks of etanercept 50 mg twice weekly (BIW), participants were randomized to 50 mg etanercept by subcutaneous injection twice weekly for 12 weeks.

group.title: Etanercept 50 mg QW + Topical
group.description: Following 12 weeks of etanercept 50 mg twice weekly, participants were randomized to 50 mg subcutaneous injection once weekly (QW) plus as needed topical agents.

measure.title: Change in Treatment Satisfaction Questionnaire for Medications (TSQM) Scores From Baseline to Weeks 12 and 24
measure.description: The TSQM is a validated questionnaire consisting of 14 questions regarding a participant's perception of the level of satisfaction or dissatisfaction with the medication they are taking. Four scales are generated: side effects, effectiveness, convenience, and global satisfaction. Optional responses are: Extremely Dissatisfied, Very Dissatisfied, Dissatisfied, Somewhat Satisfied, Satisfied, Very Satisfied, and Extremely Satisfied. From the responses, a scale score from 0 - 100 is calculated, with a higher score indicating greater satisfaction. Change was calculated as postbaseline value - Baseline value so that a positive change indicates improvement.
measure.population: Full analysis set; LOCF was used; n indicates the number of patients with available data for each scale at each time point.

outcome.title: Health Resource Utilization: Number of Participants With Visits to a Healthcare Provider
outcome.description: Participants completed a questionnaire to assess their health resource utilization (HRU) related to psoriasis. To assess the number of visits to a healthcare provider, participants answered the following questions regarding the past 4 weeks: How many times have you been to any physician’s office or urgent care clinic? How many times have you seen a nurse practitioner, a physician assistant, a psychologist, a naturopath, an acupuncturist, a chiropractor, or other healthcare professional (HCP)? The number of participants with one or more visits is reported.
outcome.population: Full Analysis Set with available data; LOCF was used.

group.title: Etanercept 50 mg BIW
group.description: Following 12 weeks of etanercept 50 mg twice weekly (BIW), participants were randomized to 50 mg etanercept by subcutaneous injection twice weekly for 12 weeks.

group.title: Etanercept 50 mg QW + Topical
group.description: Following 12 weeks of etanercept 50 mg twice weekly, participants were randomized to 50 mg subcutaneous injection once weekly (QW) plus as needed topical agents.

measure.description: Participants completed a questionnaire to assess their health resource utilization (HRU) related to psoriasis. How many times have you seen a nurse practitioner, a physician assistant, a psychologist, a naturopath, an acupuncturist, a chiropractor, or other healthcare professional (HCP)? The number of participants with one or more visits is reported.
measure.population: Full Analysis Set with available data; LOCF was used.

outcome.title: Health Resource Utilization: Number of Participants With Home Healthcare Visits
outcome.description: Participants completed a questionnaire to assess their health resource utilization (HRU) related to psoriasis. To assess the number of homecare visits, participants answered the following question regarding the past 4 weeks: How many times have you received care from a health professional in your home? The number of participants with one or more visits is reported.
outcome.population: Full Analysis Set with available data; LOCF was used.

group.title: Etanercept 50 mg BIW
group.description: Following 12 weeks of etanercept 50 mg twice weekly (BIW), participants were randomized to 50 mg etanercept by subcutaneous injection twice weekly for 12 weeks.

group.title: Etanercept 50 mg QW + Topical
group.description: Following 12 weeks of etanercept 50 mg twice weekly, participants were randomized to 50 mg subcutaneous injection once weekly (QW) plus as needed topical agents.

measure.title: Health Resource Utilization: Number of Participants With Home Healthcare Visits
measure.description: Participants completed a questionnaire to assess their health resource utilization (HRU) related to psoriasis. To assess the number of homecare visits, participants answered the following question regarding the past 4 weeks: How many times have you received care from a health professional in your home? The number of participants with one or more visits is reported.
measure.population: Full Analysis Set with available data; LOCF was used.

outcome.title: Health Resource Utilization: Number of Participants Requiring Paid Help With Chores
outcome.description: Participants completed a questionnaire to assess their health resource utilization (HRU) related to psoriasis. To assess the number of participants who needed paid help with chores, participants answered the following question regarding the past 4 weeks: How many times have you paid someone to help you do chores around the house (cleaning, maintenance, lawn care)? The number of participants who paid for help one or more times is reported.
outcome.population: Full Analysis Set with available data; LOCF was used.

group.title: Etanercept 50 mg BIW
group.description: Following 12 weeks of etanercept 50 mg twice weekly (BIW), participants were randomized to 50 mg etanercept by subcutaneous injection twice weekly for 12 weeks.

group.title: Etanercept 50 mg QW + Topical
group.description: Following 12 weeks of etanercept 50 mg twice weekly, participants were randomized to 50 mg subcutaneous injection once weekly (QW) plus as needed topical agents.

measure.title: Health Resource Utilization: Number of Participants Requiring Paid Help With Chores
measure.description: Participants completed a questionnaire to assess their health resource utilization (HRU) related to psoriasis. To assess the number of participants who needed paid help with chores, participants answered the following question regarding the past 4 weeks: How many times have you paid someone to help you do chores around the house (cleaning, maintenance, lawn care)? The number of participants who paid for help one or more times is reported.
measure.population: Full Analysis Set with available data; LOCF was used.

outcome.title: Health Resource Utilization: Number of Participants Who Needed Friend or Family Care
outcome.description: Participants completed a questionnaire to assess their health resource utilization (HRU) related to psoriasis. Participants answered the following question regarding the past 4 weeks: How many hours have you had a friend or family member take time off work to provide care or transportation? The number of participants who had paid or non-paid help for one or more hours is reported.
outcome.population: Full Analysis Set with available data; LOCF was used.

group.title: Etanercept 50 mg BIW
group.description: Following 12 weeks of etanercept 50 mg twice weekly (BIW), participants were randomized to 50 mg etanercept by subcutaneous injection twice weekly for 12 weeks.

group.title: Etanercept 50 mg QW + Topical
group.description: Following 12 weeks of etanercept 50 mg twice weekly, participants were randomized to 50 mg subcutaneous injection once weekly (QW) plus as needed topical agents.

measure.title: Health Resource Utilization: Number of Participants Who Needed Friend or Family Care
measure.description: Participants completed a questionnaire to assess their health resource utilization (HRU) related to psoriasis. Participants answered the following question regarding the past 4 weeks: How many hours have you had a friend or family member take time off work to provide care or transportation? The number of participants who had paid or non-paid help for one or more hours is reported.
measure.population: Full Analysis Set with available data; LOCF was used.

outcome.title: Health Resource Utilization: Out of Pocket Expenses
outcome.description: Participants completed a questionnaire to assess their health resource utilization (HRU) related to psoriasis. To assess out of pocket expenses, participants answered the following question regarding the past 4 weeks: Not counting study mandated visits, what out-of-pocket expenses did you spend for the management of psoriasis (i.e. costs due to travelling to doctor appointment, hospital or clinic parking costs, alternative medications)?
outcome.population: Full Analysis Set with available data; LOCF was used.

group.title: Etanercept 50 mg BIW
group.description: Following 12 weeks of etanercept 50 mg twice weekly (BIW), participants were randomized to 50 mg etanercept by subcutaneous injection twice weekly for 12 weeks.

group.title: Etanercept 50 mg QW + Topical
group.description: Following 12 weeks of etanercept 50 mg twice weekly, participants were randomized to 50 mg subcutaneous injection once weekly (QW) plus as needed topical agents.

measure.title: Health Resource Utilization: Out of Pocket Expenses
measure.description: Participants completed a questionnaire to assess their health resource utilization (HRU) related to psoriasis. To assess out of pocket expenses, participants answered the following question regarding the past 4 weeks: Not counting study mandated visits, what out-of-pocket expenses did you spend for the management of psoriasis (i.e. costs due to travelling to doctor appointment, hospital or clinic parking costs, alternative medications)?
measure.population: Full Analysis Set with available data; LOCF was used.

outcome.title: Health Resource Utilization: Employment Status
outcome.description: Participants completed a questionnaire to assess their health resource utilization (HRU) related to psoriasis. Participants were asked their employment status at Baseline and at Week 24.
outcome.population: Full Analysis Set; LOCF was used.

group.title: Etanercept 50 mg BIW
group.description: Following 12 weeks of etanercept 50 mg twice weekly (BIW), participants were randomized to 50 mg etanercept by subcutaneous injection twice weekly for 12 weeks.

group.title: Etanercept 50 mg QW + Topical
group.description: Following 12 weeks of etanercept 50 mg twice weekly, participants were randomized to 50 mg subcutaneous injection once weekly (QW) plus as needed topical agents.

measure.title: Health Resource Utilization: Employment Status
measure.description: Participants completed a questionnaire to assess their health resource utilization (HRU) related to psoriasis. Participants were asked their employment status at Baseline and at Week 24.
measure.population: Full Analysis Set; LOCF was used.

outcome.title: Health Resource Utilization: Productivity While Working
outcome.description: Participants who were employed were asked: How much did your psoriasis affect your productivity while you were working? Possible responses were: a) A great deal; b) Quite a bit; c) Somewhat; d) Minimally; e) Not at all.
outcome.population: Full Analysis Set who were employed and with available data at each time point; LOCF was used. For the Etanercept 50 mg BIW group there were 106 and 100 participants with available data at Baseline and Week 24 respectively. For the Etanercept + Topical group there were 93 and 85 participants respectively.

group.title: Etanercept 50 mg BIW
group.description: Following 12 weeks of etanercept 50 mg twice weekly (BIW), participants were randomized to 50 mg etanercept by subcutaneous injection twice weekly for 12 weeks.

group.title: Etanercept 50 mg QW + Topical
group.description: Following 12 weeks of etanercept 50 mg twice weekly, participants were randomized to 50 mg subcutaneous injection once weekly (QW) plus as needed topical agents.

measure.title: Health Resource Utilization: Productivity While Working
measure.description: Participants who were employed were asked: How much did your psoriasis affect your productivity while you were working? Possible responses were: a) A great deal; b) Quite a bit; c) Somewhat; d) Minimally; e) Not at all.
measure.population: Full Analysis Set who were employed and with available data at each time point; LOCF was used. For the Etanercept 50 mg BIW group there were 106 and 100 participants with available data at Baseline and Week 24 respectively. For the Etanercept + Topical group there were 93 and 85 participants respectively.

outcome.title: Health Resource Utilization: Number of Participants With Missed Hours From Work
outcome.description: Participants who were employed answered the following question regarding the past 4 weeks: How many hours per week did you miss from work because of your psoriasis? The number of participants with one or more missed hours of work per week is reported.
outcome.population: Full Analysis Set who were employed and with available data; LOCF was used.

group.title: Etanercept 50 mg BIW
group.description: Following 12 weeks of etanercept 50 mg twice weekly (BIW), participants were randomized to 50 mg etanercept by subcutaneous injection twice weekly for 12 weeks.

group.title: Etanercept 50 mg QW + Topical
group.description: Following 12 weeks of etanercept 50 mg twice weekly, participants were randomized to 50 mg subcutaneous injection once weekly (QW) plus as needed topical agents.

measure.title: Health Resource Utilization: Number of Participants With Missed Hours From Work
measure.description: Participants who were employed answered the following question regarding the past 4 weeks: How many hours per week did you miss from work because of your psoriasis? The number of participants with one or more missed hours of work per week is reported.
measure.population: Full Analysis Set who were employed and with available data; LOCF was used.

outcome.title: Health Resource Utilization: Ability to Perform Daily Activities
outcome.description: Participants were asked: How much did your psoriasis affect your ability to do your daily activities or household chores? Possible answers were: a) A great deal; b) Quite a bit; c) Somewhat; d) Minimally; e) Not at all.
outcome.population: Full Analysis Set; LOCF was used.

group.title: Etanercept 50 mg BIW
group.description: Following 12 weeks of etanercept 50 mg twice weekly (BIW), participants were randomized to 50 mg etanercept by subcutaneous injection twice weekly for 12 weeks.

group.title: Etanercept 50 mg QW + Topical
group.description: Following 12 weeks of etanercept 50 mg twice weekly, participants were randomized to 50 mg subcutaneous injection once weekly (QW) plus as needed topical agents.

measure.title: Health Resource Utilization: Ability to Perform Daily Activities
measure.description: Participants were asked: How much did your psoriasis affect your ability to do your daily activities or household chores? Possible answers were: a) A great deal; b) Quite a bit; c) Somewhat; d) Minimally; e) Not at all.
measure.population: Full Analysis Set; LOCF was used.

outcome.title: Number of Participants With Adverse Events
outcome.description: An adverse event (AE) is defined as any untoward medical occurrence in a clinical trial participant. A serious adverse event is defined as an adverse event that meets at least 1 of the following serious criteria: • fatal, • life threatening, • requires in-patient hospitalization or prolongation of existing hospitalization, • results in persistent or significant disability/incapacity, • congenital anomaly/birth defect, and/or • other significant medical hazard.
outcome.population: Safety analysis was based on treatment received, regardless of group assignment. 177 patients are included in group A, including 144 patients randomized to group A, 23 patients who were non-randomized and 10 patients randomized to group B but never received topical agents; Group B includes 133 patients who received etanercept plus ≥1 topical agent.

group.title: Etanercept Monotherapy
group.description: All participants who received etanercept at any time during the study, who never used a topical agent, regardless of treatment assignment, including those participants who were not randomized at Week 12.

group.title: Etanercept + Topical
group.description: All participants who used a topical agent at least once during the study, regardless of treatment group assignment.

measure.title: Number of Participants With Adverse Events
measure.description: An adverse event (AE) is defined as any untoward medical occurrence in a clinical trial participant. A serious adverse event is defined as an adverse event that meets at least 1 of the following serious criteria: • fatal, • life threatening, • requires in-patient hospitalization or prolongation of existing hospitalization, • results in persistent or significant disability/incapacity, • congenital anomaly/birth defect, and/or • other significant medical hazard.
measure.population: Safety analysis was based on treatment received, regardless of group assignment. 177 patients are included in group A, including 144 patients randomized to group A, 23 patients who were non-randomized and 10 patients randomized to group B but never received topical agents; Group B includes 133 patients who received etanercept plus ≥1 topical agent.

class.title: AE leading to discontinuation of study treatment
AE leading to discontinuation from study

reported_events.desc: Safety analysis was based on treatment received, regardless of group assignment. 177 patients are included in group A, including 144 patients randomized to group A, 23 patients who were non-randomized and 10 patients randomized to group B but never received topical agents; Group B includes 133 patients who received etanercept plus ≥1 topical agent.

group.title: Etanercept Monotherapy
group.description: All participants who received etanercept at any time during the study, who never used a topical agent, regardless of treatment assignment, including those participants who were not randomized at Week 12.

group.title: Etanercept + Topical
group.description: All participants who used a topical agent at least once during the study, regardless of treatment group assignment.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: The Clinical Trial Agreement generally does not restrict an investigator's discussion of trial results aftercompletion. The Agreement permits Amgen a limited period of time to review material discussing trial results (typically up to 45 days and possible extension). Amgen may remove confidential information, but authors have final control and approval of publication content. For multicenter studies, the investigator agrees not to publish any results before the first multi-center publication.
